title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
Mean vector \(\mu' = (\mu_1 , \mu_2, \dots , \mu_k)'; [k>2]\)
Condition of PDF:

\(\int_x f(x) dx = 1\)
\(f(x) \ge 0\)

Condition of PMF:

\(\sum_x p(x)=1\)
\(0\le p(x) \le 1\)

Example:
\(f(x) = kx^2; [0\le x \le 1]\) is a pdf. Then find k
Answer: Thus f(x) is a pdf,
\(\therefore \int_x f(x) dx = 1\)
\(\Rightarrow \int_0^1 kx^2 dx = 1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{k}{3} [x^3]_0^1=1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{k}{3} \times 1 = 1\)
\(\therefore k = 3\)
Therfore, the pdf is \(f(x) = 3x^2; [0\le x \le 1]\)











X and Y are random variable and the joint pdf is, \(f(x, y) = cx^3y \\ 0 \le x \le 1, y \ge 0\)

Find \(r_{xy}\)

title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
X and Y are random variable and the joint pdf is, \(f(x, y) = cx^3y \\ 0 \le x \le 1, y \ge 0\)

Find \(r_{xy}\)

title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
Introduction
A vector valued random variable \(X = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_p)'\) is said to have a multivarite normal distribution with mean vector \(\mu = (\mu_1, \mu_2, \dots , \mu_p)'\) and variance-covariance matrix \(\Sigma = \{\sigma_{ij}\}, i, j = 1, 2, \dots, p\) if its pdf is defined as, \[f(X)=\frac{1}{(2\Pi)^{\frac{p}{2}} |\Sigma |^\frac{1}{2}} exp\Big[ -\frac{1}{2} (X-\mu)'\Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu) \Big] \] or, \[f(X)=(2\Pi)^{-\frac{p}{2}} |\Sigma |^{-\frac{1}{2}} exp\Big[ -\frac{1}{2} (X-\mu)'\Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu) \Big] ----(1)\] \[-\infty<x_i<\infty, -\infty<\mu_i < \infty \\ \sigma_{ij} > 0; i=1, 2, \dots, p\]

title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
Derivation of MND
For univariate, \[f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma^2}} exp\Big[-\frac12 \frac{(x-\mu)^2}{\sigma^2}\Big]\] \[\Rightarrow f(x) = k \times  exp\Big[-\frac12 \frac{(x-\mu)(x-\mu)}{\sigma^2}\Big]\] \[\Rightarrow f(x) = k \times exp\Big[-\frac12 (x-\mu)' (\sigma^2)^{-1}(x-\mu)\Big]\]
Now, for p component multivarite case, we have, \(X=(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_p)'= \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \dots \\ x_p \end{bmatrix}, \mu=\begin{bmatrix} \mu_1 \\ \mu_2 \\ \dots \\ \mu_p \end{bmatrix}\)
and \(\sigma^2\) is replaced by \(\Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} & \sigma_{12} & \dots & \sigma_{1p} \\ \sigma_{21} & \sigma_{22} & \dots & \sigma_{2p} \\ \dots & \dots & \dots & \dots \\ \sigma_{p1} & \sigma_{p_2} & \dots & \sigma_{pp} \end{bmatrix}\)
\[\therefore f(X) = k \times exp\Big[ -\frac12(X-\mu)' \Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu)\Big] ---(2)\] \[\infty < x_i , \mu_i<\infty; \sigma_{ij} > 0\]
Here, k i sconstant that can be determined by the integration over the range of the components variable.
\(f(X)\) is non-negative because \(\Sigma^{-1}\) is a positive definite and \((X-\mu)'\Sigma^{-1}(X-\mu) \ge 0\)
\[\therefore \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dots \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(X) dx_1 \dots dx_p = 1 ----(3)\] \[\Rightarrow \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dots \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} k \times exp\Big[ -\frac12(X-\mu)' \Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu)\Big]  dx_1 \dots dx_p = 1\] \[\Rightarrow \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dots \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} exp\Big[ -\frac12(X-\mu)' \Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu)\Big]  dx_1 \dots dx_p = \frac 1k = k^* \text{ (say)} \] \(----(4)\)
We use the fact that if \(\Sigma^{-1}\) is a positive definite, then there exists a non-singular matrix C such that, \(C'\Sigma^{-1}C=I ----(5)\)
Now, let \(X-\mu = CY\), where \(Y=\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \dots \\ y_p \end{bmatrix}\),\(Y'Y = \begin{bmatrix} y_1 & y_2 & \dots & y_p \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \dots \\ y_p \end{bmatrix} = \sum y_i^2\)
\(\therefore dX = |C|dY\)
Then, \((X-\mu)' \Sigma^{-1} (X-\mu) = Y'C'\Sigma^{-1}CY = Y'IY=Y'Y = \sum_{i=1}^p y_i^2\)
And the Jacobian transformation \(J = mod|C|\)

title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
Properties of Quadratic Form

A quadratic form \(Q=X'AX\) is a homogeneous polynomial of degree two with any number of variables.
If \(X \sim N_p (\mu, \Sigma)\), then the quardatic form \(Q_1 = X'AX\) and \(Q_2 =X'BX\) are independent iff \(A\Sigma B=0\).
If \(X \sim N_p (0, I)\), then the quardatic form \(Q = X'AX\) follows \(\chi^2\)-distribution with k-df.
If \(X \sim N_p (\mu, I)\), then the quardatic form \(Q = X'AX \sim \chi'^2\) (Non central \(\chi^2\)-distribution) with k-df and non-centrility parameter, \(\lambda=\frac12 \mu'A\mu\).
If \(X \sim N_p (0, \Sigma)\), then the quardatic form \(Q = X'AX\) follows \(\chi^2\)-distribution with k-df.
If \(X \sim N_p (\mu, \Sigma)\), then the m.g.f of quadratic form \(Q = X'AX\) is \(M_Q (t) = (1-2d_{ii}t)^{-\frac k2}\).

title: Multivariate Distribution
text:
Use/Application

It is used in multivariate normal distribution and analysis.
Sometimes is used in ANOVA and congruent reduction.
It is used in both central and non-central sampling distribution.
To find maximum and minimum values function of the severil variables.
It is used in Wishart and Hotelings’ \(T^2\)-distribution.
It is used in derivation of \(\chi'^2\) (Non central \(\chi^2\)).
… And many more

title: Stochastic Processes and Acturial Models
text:
Variable: Values varies form Individual to individual.
Experiment: Repeation fo an event is called experiment.
Random Variable: Random variable is a variable that associate to probability. Random variable is an stochastic variable.
Stichastic Processes: Stochastic process or random process is a collection of random variables orderd by an index set. Let \(X_0, X_1, X_2, \dots;\) be a set of random variables; that form a stochastic process ordered by the discrete index set \(\{1, 2, 3, \dots\}\).
Notation: For discrete index set, \(\{X_n:n=0,1,2,\dots\}\) and \(\{Y_t:t\geq0\}\) with continuous index set \(\{t:t\geq0\}\).
Bivariate: Discrete and Continuous (i) Discrete time, Discrete state space (DD) (ii) Discrete time, Continuous state space (DC) (iii) Continuous time, Discrete state space (CD) (iv) Continuous time, Continuous state space (CC)

title: Stochastic Processes and Acturial Models
Stochastic Processes and Acturial Models
text:
Binomial Distribution
\(p(x) = {n\choose x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x}; x = 0, 1, 2, \dots , n\)
\(p(s) = \sum_{k=0}^n p_{k} s^k\)$
\(=p_0 s^0 + p_1 s^1 +p_2 s^2 + \dots + p_n s^n\)
\(={n \choose 0} p^0q^{n-0}s^0 + {n \choose 1} p^1q^{n-1}s^1 +{n \choose 2} p^2q^{n-2}s^2+ \dots + {n \choose n} p^nq^{0}s^n\)
\(\therefore p(s)=(q+ps)^n\)

title: Stochastic Processes and Acturial Models
text:
2 states and m-steps Markov Chain
\(P = \begin{pmatrix} q & p \\ p & q \end{pmatrix}\)
\(P^2 = \begin{pmatrix} q^2+p^2 & 2pq \\ 2pq & q^2+p^2 \end{pmatrix}\)
Now, \(q^2+p^2 = \frac{2q^2+2p^2}{2} = \frac{q^2+2pq+p^2 +q^2-2pq+p^2}{2}\)
\(=\frac{(p+q)^2 + (q-p)^2}{2} = \frac{1+(q-p)^2}{2} = \frac{1}{2}+\frac{(q-p)^2}{2}\)
And, \(2pq=\frac{4pq}2=\frac{p^2+2pq+q^2-(q^2 - 2pq+p^2)}{2}\)
\(=\frac{(p+q)^2 - (q-p)^2}{2} = \frac{1-(q-p)^2}{2} = \frac{1}{2}-\frac{(q-p)^2}{2}\)
\(\therefore P^{(2)} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^2}2 & \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^2}2 \\ \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^2}2 & \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^2}2\end{pmatrix}\)
Similarly, \(P^{(3)} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^3}2 & \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^3}2 \\ \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^3}2 & \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^3}2\end{pmatrix}\)
\(\therefore P^{(m)} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^m}2 & \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^m}2 \\ \frac 12-\frac{(q-p)^m}2 & \frac 12+\frac{(q-p)^m}2\end{pmatrix}\)
Here, \(\frac{(q-p)^m}2\) is the stochastic part and \(\frac12\) is the deterministic part
When, \(m \to \infty\), then \(\frac{(q-p)^m}2 \to 0\). So the matrix tends to deterministic from stochastic and the P becomes,
\(P^{(m)}=\begin{pmatrix} \frac12 & \frac12 \\ \frac12 & \frac 12\end{pmatrix}\)

title: Complex Variable and Transformations
text:
Number: A number is a mathematical objects used to count, measure and also label. The original examples are the natural numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 and so on. A notational symbol that represents a number is called a numeral. In addition, to their use in counting and measuring, numerals are often used for labels (as with telephone numbers), for ordering (as with serial numbers) and for codes (as with ISBNs).



Complex number: A complex number is a number that can be expressed in the form \(a+ib\), where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit satisfying the property that \(i^2 = -1\).
If \(z=a+ib\), then a is called real part and b is called the imaginary part of z, which are denoted by \(Re\{z\}\) and \(Im\{z\}\) respectively.
Example: 1. \(2+5i\), where \(a=2,b=5\) 2. \(3-i\), where \(a=3,b=-1\)
Here, 1 and 2 are complex numbers because they can be expressed in the form \(a+ib\).



Complex Variable: If \(z=a+ib\) is a complex number satisfying \(i^2=-1\), then a is called real part of z and b is called imaginary part of z, which are denoted by \(Re\{z\}\) and \(Im\{z\}\) respectively.
The symbol z, which can stand for any complex number, is a complex variable.
Example: \(z_1 = 2+3i\) and \(z_2=5-3i\) Here, \(z_1\) and \(z_2\) are complex number.












Real Numbers: All numbers which are situated on straight line are called real numbers. The set of real numbers is denoted by \(\mathbb{R}\) and defined as,
\[\mathbb{R} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\} = \{\mathbb{Q} \cup \mathbb{Q}' \}\]
Real Line: All the numbers positive or negative, rational or irrational can be represented on a straight line, say the axis of x which is called real line.








Commutative: \(a+b = b+a\), \(ab = ba\)
Associative: \((a+b)+c=a+(b+c)\), \((ab)c=a(bc)\)
Distributive: \(a(b+c) = ab + ac\), \((a+b)c=ac+bc\)
Identity: \(a+0=a\), \(0+a=a\), \(a\cdot1=a\), \(1\cdot a = a\)

\[\mathbb{Q} = \{\text{ Set of Rational Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{Z} = \{\text{ Set of Integer Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{N} = \{\text{ Set of Natural Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{R} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{C} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\}\]
\[\mathbb{N} \subset \mathbb{Z} \subset \mathbb{Q} \subset \mathbb{R}\subset \mathbb{C}\]






























Note: উপরের অংশ থেকে হাফ সেট প্রশ্ন হবে

title: Complex Variable and Transformations
text:
Real Numbers: All numbers which are situated on straight line are called real numbers. The set of real numbers is denoted by \(\mathbb{R}\) and defined as,
\[\mathbb{R} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\} = \{\mathbb{Q} \cup \mathbb{Q}' \}\]
Real Line: All the numbers positive or negative, rational or irrational can be represented on a straight line, say the axis of x which is called real line.








Commutative: \(a+b = b+a\), \(ab = ba\)
Associative: \((a+b)+c=a+(b+c)\), \((ab)c=a(bc)\)
Distributive: \(a(b+c) = ab + ac\), \((a+b)c=ac+bc\)
Identity: \(a+0=a\), \(0+a=a\), \(a\cdot1=a\), \(1\cdot a = a\)

\[\mathbb{Q} = \{\text{ Set of Rational Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{Z} = \{\text{ Set of Integer Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{N} = \{\text{ Set of Natural Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{R} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\}\] \[\mathbb{C} = \{\text{ Set of Real Numbers }\}\]

title: Practical
text:
Topics

Fitting of Multivariate Normal Distribution
Fitting of Non-central \(\chi^2\), t and F distribution with their properties
Fitting of Hotelling’s \(T^2\), Wishart distribution and Multivariate t-distribution
Fitting of Multivariate Mixture Distributions: Mixture of multivariate normal distributions and its properties, Mixture of multivariate t-distributions and its properties.

Problem 1

Generate 1500 random sample
Draw box plot and marginal pdf of \(f(x_i), i=1, 2, \dots, 5\)
Find \(\hat \mu, \hat \Sigma\) using MLE
Find RMSE
